Honda Odyssey EX


Last month, PM conducted a comparison test of the current crop of minivans (see "Family Trucksters," Nov. 1999, page 82). On the one hand, they turned out to be pretty much alike: four doors, plenty of room for kids and their belongings, proven front-wheel- drive drive-trains, easy to run to the grocery or the lumber yard. But on the other hand, they also proved to be fairly different from one another. The winner of that test was Honda's Odyssey. It won for all the reasons that we've enjoyed the last year with ours.
True to their Honda heritage, the V6 and four-speed automatic transmission perform with world-class character: smooth, quiet, with a touch more oomph than the competition. In other basic features--noise level inside the cabin, space, comfort, convenience of controls--Odyssey stands at least equal to the best of its competitors.
But despite its winning ways and features, our long-term tester showed a few niggling problems toward the end of the test. For one, the keyless remote never worked right. We've mentioned this problem in earlier reports, and right up to the end of the test the system was annoyingly balky.
We had a recalcitrant sliding passenger-side door that compounded our confusion with the keyless remote. But that, as well as the a/c that shut down when both front and rear units were running simultaneously, was fixed under warranty.
Despite these irritations we think that this is one superb execution of the minivan theme. And the foldaway third seat beats the heck out of any removable third seat arrangement. If you take a Chrysler van as the design benchmark, then the Odyssey beats the current standard, with its double power sliding doors and rear seat. It has to be noted also that our long-term test van was a very early production unit and the more recently built Odyssey that was used in our comparison test exhibited none of the glitches that our long-termer did.
We'll miss our Odyssey. It's one nasty-looking minivan. Unlike most, this minivan has a stance and real visual presence.

Test Summary: Honda Odyssey EX
